bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Arlington County was originally named Alexandria County. It was formed from a portion of Fairfax County that Virginia in 1789 ceded to the federal government for use as the site of a new national capital. In 1801 the area officially became part of the District of Columbia, although Congress named it Alexandria County. By an act of 9 July 1846, Congress returned the county to Virginia, and the General Assembly extended the commonwealth's jurisdiction over the region effective 20 March 1847. By an act of assembly passed 16 March 1920, the county's name was changed to Arlington, the name of the Custis family mansion (the home of Robert E. Lee), which is located in the county. An urban county, Arlington contains no incorporated towns or cities. The county courthouse is in the county.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Arlington County (Va.) Judgments and Criminal Suits, 1783-1896 (bulk 1786-1859), consist primarily of civil suits and commonwealth causes heard in the Hustings Court of Alexandria and the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia. The majority of civil suits relate to matters of debt.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material

scopecontent.p: To recover the penalty imposed by law for carrying a slave out of the Commonwealth of Virginia without consent of owner. Runaway slave named Charles. Depositions included.

did.unittitle: William Short vs. John Brown Cutting , 1808 Nov..

scopecontent.p: Short was minister to Holland, Spain, and Russia. Includes correspondence re: international political environment. He was close to Thomas Jefferson. Cutting was an attorney for impressed American seaman in London. Also associated with Jefferson.

scopecontent.p: (Writ of Habeas Corpus) Duffy was arrested and jailed for attempting to murder members of his family. He was accused of putting ratsbane in a kettle of boiling water for tea to be drank at supper.

did.unittitle: United States vs. Leven Gales, 1821 May.

scopecontent.p: Defendant was a free black. Charged and found guilty of seducing a slave named Fielder by means of false papers to abscond from the estate of his master, Bushrod Washington. He attempted to pass off Fielder as his nephew.

did.unittitle: United States vs. Emily, a slave, 1821 Nov..

scopecontent.p: Defendant was charged with attempted to destroy her infant child.

did.unittitle: Sampson Sumly vs. Solomon Lorins, 1822 May.

scopecontent.p: Plaintiff was a free person of color. He sued the defendant, a sea captain, for taking off the plaintiff's son, a minor aged 20, without his consent and having him in another state, or in this case, the West Indies. Plaintiff sued for loss income ($2000) he would have made from his son's employment as a caulker. The jury awarded him $45 depending on the judge's opinion. The judge sided with the defendant.

did.unittitle: David Black, etc. vs. Charles Bradford, 1823 May.

scopecontent.p: Defendant accused of obstructing the plaintiff's ancient lights.

did.unittitle: Richard Gardner vs. Columbian Insurance Company, 1824 May.

scopecontent.p: Large suit involving ship sank in Rio Janeiro. Numerous exhibits and depositions. Mutiny perhaps involved.

did.unittitle: Christian Clarke vs. Corporation of Washington, 1827 April.

scopecontent.p: Plaintiff suing for the $100,000 he won in a national lottery sponsored by city of Washington, D.C. Winning ticket used as exhibit. Background on lottery. Case heard in Supreme Court.

did.unittitle: Ashby and Stribling vs. Columbian Insurance Company, 1828 April.

scopecontent.p: Large suit involving ship sank by bad weather, perhaps a hurricane. Numerous exhibits and depositions. Newspaper used as exhibit by plaintiff. American Beacon, 1825 June 18.

did.unittitle: Samuel H. Smith vs. Thomas K. Beale, 1838 Oct..

scopecontent.p: Plaintiff was treasurer of Washington National Monument Society. Suit involves an agent of society responsible with collecting pledges for the Washington Monument in Alabama. Suit includes correspondence from agent detailing his travels and travails in Alabama.

did.unittitle: United States vs. William Hudland , 1838 Nov..

scopecontent.p: Includes Presidential pardon signed by Martin Van Buren.
